data.text: To rob (a town, for example) of goods or valuables, especially after capture.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The looting or pillaging of a captured city or town.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Any of various light, dry, strong wines from Spain and the Canary Islands, imported to England in the 1500s and 1600s.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A bag, especially one made of strong material for holding grain or objects in bulk.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: The amount that a sack can hold.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A short loose-fitting garment for women and children.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: finally got the sack after a year of ineptitude.

data.text: A bed, mattress, or sleeping bag.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
